Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 25f45fc0839f104a4c3610bef531083df7160f08
The roles listed here don't quite line up with the headings below, for example the headings below contain "Approver". Also "TOF member" listed here isn't discussed?
ACK.  I will line these names up.  I wasn't sure how to deduplicate the "tof membership" stuff, probably should've listed that as a TODO.
Done
Where are sponsors discussed?  May want to link a reference since this is the first mention.
Ack
What do you think about calling these "expectations" rather than "requirements"?
Seems reasonable.  "requirements" was pulled from kubernettes, but I like your wording better.
Done
I'm a bit torn about specific numbers here. I think it's more of a trust thing than a time thing (aside from having to build trust over time)?

once again, this is copied from k8s.  Happy to change it, but I'm not sure we want to.  The primary intent from my perspective is to explicitly codify the pattern of "I've just signed the CLA, have never participated before, but please accept this large code contribution of a new daemon and make me the maintainer" pattern that we've seen before.  I'm happy to adjust the number one way or another, but I think having a non-zero number helps to codify some expectations we've seen here.
Right, maybe s/requirements/expectations/ as suggested above will help how I feel about this.
I made the changes to expectations.
Done
delete 'a'
Ack
Done
I'm not sure this makes sense to me.  Someone can be sponsored to be an approver by someone who is only a reviewer?
nope, this was a mistake.  reviewers needs removed from this sentence.
Done
Is the distinction between approver and owner something we already support in a tooling sense?

Only kind of, and it's relatively new.  It's the difference between someone that's listed as in an OWNERS file without restriction, or someone that's listed in OWNERS for a particular portion of the codebase.  We could very likely get some better tooling around it, but I think it makes sense to separate out the roles of "can approve some code that follows the existing standard" and "can drive the overall direction/approve wide-sweeping changes to the standard"
Oh, right, that was probably reading comprehension fail on my part.
Looks pretty reasonable to me overall...a smattering of minor issues and questions.
Thanks everyone for your comments.  I'll give this round of the doc a little bit for folks to discuss, then I'll start making fixups and submit a new one early next week.

Are they? This seems a little weird as many people become members purely to fix some small thing and then will likely go back to doing whatever it is they really care about. Most open source projects will see lots of transients and I don't really see why they would be expected to remain active.

That's a fair point, but I'm not sure how to codify "you should own the things that you produce".  I would note that there's not any teeth behind this statement (although we could probably point to Andrews doc when it gets merged), but the general expectation that to keep a membership, you be active seems reasonable to me.  What do other folks think?  Is there a way to word this to keep some amount of the intent while still allowing drive-by fixes?

I think the whole notion of membership is a little confused.  People contribute code.  It will either be maintained or it won't.  If it isn't, and it becomes a burden, someone should remove it.

Maybe to codify that, you could put it as one of the responsibilities of approvers/maintainers (although I think regular code contributors are free to do this as well) - something along the lines of: maintainers remove previous code contributions that are dead code, unmaintained or impede forward progress in other areas of the project.
Added a blurb to the Maintainer section.  PTAL
This link could use a corresponding entry at the bottom of the doc like the others.
Ack

This may be deep in bikeshed territory, but to me "substantial" sounds like something larger than I think we might want here (brings to mind triple-digit LoC patches)..."non-trivial" perhaps?  It strikes me as slightly less vague, and maybe a bit more easily attainable.
Maybe, but it's pretty easy to come up with 5 non-trivial changes and not have experience enough to perform general reviews for a project.

@wak agreed.  Yes, 5 is the lower floor, and I'm happy to adjust up or down if we think it should be a different number, and I realize it's subjective.  The key is that "reviewer" is fairly attainable in short order, especially given the users inability to approve patches directly.
Grammar nit: "of the codebase"?
Ack
Done

Really? In what other open source project is this ever the case? I guess I've never seen it written out for any other project, and generally you need some clout to get larger changes merged. But this seems a little weird and exclusive depending on how "large" we are talking.

> Really? In what other open source project is this ever the case? I guess I've never seen it written out for any other project, and generally you need some clout to get larger changes merged. But this seems a little weird and exclusive depending on how "large" we are talking.


This line is literally quoted from Kubernettes, so at the very least K8S has this rule.  I'd also point out that this is a "may", not a "shall".  We arguably already have this rule, given that when people ask for new repos, we explicitly require them to call out who the maintainer is, so it seemed on par to me with the current status quo.  Maybe there's a rephrase that would make it more clear?

Is the the objective here is to head off requests for large code dumps developed behind a firewall with no community input on the design?

What is wrong with accepting large contributions that are high quality and possibly useful from someone that has never done a review?  I wonder if we should document that too.

> Is the the objective here is to head off requests for large code dumps developed behind a firewall with no community input on the design?
> 
> What is wrong with accepting large contributions that are high quality and possibly useful from someone that has never done a review?  I wonder if we should document that too.

Not quite.  I would say the intent here is to head off requests for merges of large features for which the submitter has no intent of maintaining it, or accepting community code changes for it.  Code that nobody uses or maintains is a burden.  There are a large number of repos that aren't enabled on any platform, and don't respond to review requests, that's what this is trying to avoid.
Axe the word "subproject" here?  I had assumed that term referred to things in their own separate repos, which platform meta-layers aren't.
ACK.  Will remove.
Done
Nit: pluralize.
Ack
DOne
Might be slightly clearer to phrase as "in the main OpenBMC repo" or similar IMO.
Ack
Done, included link.

Do new platforms in the community need this? Might not be obvious to some as adding a platform seems like a way someone would enter the community. Maybe we need a less strict repo / area users can check into without needing sponsorship or ability to run code changes on a platform.

The intent here is that the bar is low, and most platform reviews take longer than this to submit anyway, so my thinking was that this number doesn't stop someone entering the community with a new platform.  The other intent is to discourage the "drive-by" platform submissions that we've been seeing, and porting a platform almost certainly takes 3 months or longer.  Roughly half (stats needed) of the platforms we've ever accepted have had to be deleted eventually from lack of maintainership.  The other thing to keep in mind is that if there's a platform that can be done in less than 3 months, it's pretty trivial for one of the core maintainers to maintain it for a few months until the user gets their tenure (this has happened in the past).

With all that said, what change do you think we should make here?  Strike this out entirely?  If other folks agree, I could be ok with that.

I'm not entirely clear on the meaning here, perhaps some rewording would help...is the intent that only existing platform maintainers can accept a new platform?  I guess I would have expected that to require approval from someone in the top-level OWNERS file -- is maintainership of platform X a sufficient qualification to approve some unrelated platform Y?

> I'm not entirely clear on the meaning here, perhaps some rewording would help...is the intent that only existing platform maintainers can accept a new platform?


No.  The intent here is that we _probably_ will not accept a platform from someone that doesn't intend to maintain it.  Agreed, I could word that intent better.  I'll take a stab at it.

>  I guess I would have expected that to require approval from someone in the top-level OWNERS file -- is maintainership of platform X a sufficient qualification to approve some unrelated platform Y?

Agreed, I could see how that would be confusing.  Will rephrase to match the intent.
Reworded.

Is this an OWNERS key we actually use?  I don't recall seeing any instances of it, and a quick github search of the openbmc org doesn't seem to turn up any hits: https://github.com/search?q=org%3Aopenbmc+approvers&type=code
Nope, it should be "owner".  ACK  will fix.
Done
missing "the" again
Ack
Done
"of the codebase"
Done

Do we have any existing examples of this?  From a small random sampling of the OWNERS files we've got at the moment, they all seem to have the same comment block describing the schema of the file format, but nothing about the process of getting oneself into it.

> Do we have any existing examples of this?

One such example is bmcweb: https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/OWNERS

>  From a small random sampling of the OWNERS files we've got at the moment, they all seem to have the same comment block describing the schema of the file format, but nothing about the process of getting oneself into it.

I should rephrase this.  The intent of this is that if there are requirements specific to that repo, they be outlined within the owners file for that repo.  I think a lot of our repos fall into the base rules, so no specific terminology is required.  I can rephrase to make it sound less like a requirement.
Rephrased.
Grammar nit: "Ensuring" (for consistency with the other lines)
Ack
Done
These paths don't exist in our docs repo; not sure off the top of my head if there's some appropriate place we could point them instead...
ACK.  Will fix up the links.
Done
Doc is ready for another round of review.  Sorry for the lag.
I don't have any objections. This is a nice reference.
Latest update is just a rebase/formatting fix.
Sorry I'm late to the party.  I just had some minor feedback/questions.  +1 because this is a great start.

I updated this with all the obvious changes, and tried to respond to the rest.  I said it a couple times below, but I'll repeat up here, would it be ok to treat this as a base (even if it doesn't merge, but a merge would be ideal) and treat changes as incremental (feel free to stack patches) where we can discussion individual category naming, and some of the exact wording, so that the folks that have already reviewed and +1ed this one aren't having to hunt for changes?

>  would it be ok to treat this as a base (even if it doesn't merge, but a merge would be ideal) and treat changes as incremental 

Fine by me - I hope this was implied by a '+1' ...
Cool.  I figured, but I didn't want you to feel like you were overriden.

I don't think anyone expects everyone listed in a CLA to be an active contributor.  There are many people listed in CLAs that are not active contributors.  Is that OK?

FYA the org member list was a big hassle to maintain, just because of the number people involved.  Also, GitHub doesn't allow delegating this, so you have to be an organization owner to add/remove members.  So I stopped doing it.

I don't think we have a use case for making people org members other than showcasing their involvement.  But this is a lot of work to enable that.  I think we'd be better served publishing individual contributor metrics that highlight who is doing a bunch of work.

Would a more suitable role/table entry be

 `code contributor | none | executed CLA | merged code`

> I don't think anyone expects everyone listed in a CLA to be an active contributor.  There are many people listed in CLAs that are not active contributors.  Is that OK?

Obviously that's ok.

> 
> FYA the org member list was a big hassle to maintain, just because of the number people involved.  Also, GitHub doesn't allow delegating this, so you have to be an organization owner to add/remove members.  So I stopped doing it.
> 
> I don't think we have a use case for making people org members other than showcasing their involvement.  But this is a lot of work to enable that.  I think we'd be better served publishing individual contributor metrics that highlight who is doing a bunch of work.
> 
> Would a more suitable role/table entry be
> 
>  `code contributor | none | executed CLA | merged code`

Rather than no expectations, I put following the code of conduct just so there's SOMETHING.  I didn't want to explicitly say there's no expectations, because that seems ripe for abuse.  Hopefully that works for use.
Nice, thanks.
it feels a little odd to be making assertions about writing code in the reviewer section...
Removed authorship.
what happens if they don't?  they are no longer established community members?  this feels backwards - you become an established community member by demonstrating the  things you list.

In practice, I think there are multiple organizational checks.  I'm not sure putting consequences in this document fits with the overall theme or voice that this is trying to convey.  Thusfar in the project, the consequences part seems to not be all that necessary, or at least we don't seem to swing that hammer often.  I don't think documenting it would help.

With that said, in the interest of getting this merged, I'm happy to do whatever sounds good to you, and treat anything i personally don't think should be here as incremental improvement in another patch.

> I'm not sure putting consequences in this document fits with the overall theme or voice that this is trying to convey.

Agreed.  My question was rhetorical.  My point was that you become an established community member -after- demonstrating the behaviors your list.  They way it is currently worded sounds (to me) like you are bestowed with established community member status and along with that are expected to behave in a certain way.
I think a lot of people view "reviewers" as "I'd like to be notified when there is a change".  I worry a little bit that we'll have a hard time changing the meaning of this.

Second rule in CS, naming things is hard;

the intent is to have 4 classes:
0. People that send in code.
1. People that should be notified, and are in the process of becoming a maintainer, but don't hold permissions to do merges yet due to time or technical background.
2. People that hold permissions to merge code to a single component.
3. People that are expected to maintain the codebase as a whole, not a single component.

I'm happy to change any of the names if there's other suggestions, but reviewer is what we use in the OWNERS file today.  If you just want to be notified, gerrit has lots of facilities for that.

> but reviewer is what we use in the OWNERS file today.

Agreed, but I don't think #1 is how people think about the reviewer entry in the OWNERS file.  I could be wrong.

In my mind a reviewer is just another contributor - its just their contribution is peer review instead of code.  You get into #2 and #3 by doing #0 and #1. You can be a reviewer without being in the process of becoming a maintainer.  I've never really seen the point of the Reviewer entry.

No suggestions or requests for change..just offering a perspective.
ACK.  Your perspective is noted and I agree with it, just not sure how that would codify in this kind of doc.
Do they need to have demonstrated proficiency with bitbake metadata?
Added to expectations.  I thought that was kind of implied if you submitted a platform with correct bitbake layers, but it doesn't hurt to be explicit.
Thanks.
I believe most people would expect to see "maintainer" here.
Is it ok if we treat that as a followup discussion in the next patch (which I will push).  I think the exact names we use are much less important than the actual content.

Yes it is OK to treat as followup.  I agree the content is much more important -  assuming the motivation behind using a less expected name isn't because we want to change the de-facto meaning of the role.
Is it important to distinguish this role from the approver role?

I kinda thought so because one is arguably responsible for the tree, and general usability, the other might be responsible for just one minor section, like a security registry or something, and might not be responsible for the whole tree.
Mostly nits I think.  Overall in agreement.
Do we need any words about "how do I resign from these roles"?
In this it's implied, but we could be explicit.  I'd like to see that in another addition to this.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/63567
I don't think we actually do this for most people now?  @brad
Shoot, brad already commented this, and I fixed it in one spot.  Missed this one.  FIxed.
Or be covered by a CCLA?  Not sure how pedantic we want to be.

I can probably just drop to "Submit a CLA"  This doc shouldn't enforce how to do that.

Removed mention of the mailing list here.

The wording here makes it seem like "you don't have permission to review until you are reviewer" but I think you intend it to mean "are technically competent enough to review code".  (Probably want different wording than that.)

yeah, that's a fair point.  Maybe "Reviewers are capable of reviewing code for quality...." ?

Changed to that.
self-nominate or be (drop comma, add 'or').  Apply throughout.
ACK
I'd lean towards 6 months but no big debate.
I'm leaving at 9 for now.  Happy to discuss 6, but I'll follow up in another patch.  My thinking is that realistically this isn't going to be the thing that holds folks up.

I would kind of like something here of "Keep abreast of technical changes to the overall project and maintain and/or delegate maintenance of the subproject to keep it aligned with the overall project."

Maybe this is already codified in this line and isn't necessary but it seems to me like a weakness of the current maintainer structure.
Put your line into the latest revision.
You removed comma but missed 'or'.
Fixed
Is there a missing (or extraneous) word here or something?  (c.f. "test bugs", not sure how to interpret that)
This was taken from the k8s doc, but it amounts to being assigned bugs for failing tests.
I mentioned "Apply throughout" because there are a few copypastas of this phrase.
Sorry, missed that;
Do we have a way of distinguishing approvers from owners in the OWNERS file?  Currently the "defined by" of both refer to the same key (`owners`).

My reading was that an “approver” is over a subset of the subproject and thus is associated with a path match rather than the top level.  Maybe I was reading too much into it and this should be explicit if it is what Ed intended.

Yep, what stwx said was the intent.

> Currently the "defined by" of both refer to the same key

The intent was if you're listed as an OWNER of the whole repo, or if you're listed as an OWNER of a subdir.

I'm not sure how to capture that here.
Might want to add "...of the subproject repo" here I think (just to clarify that it's not referring to the openbmc/openbmc one).
added "subproject"
